Award.AwardTitle: On the Geometry of Moduli Space and Kahler-Einstein Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator will work on fundamental problems in differential geometry. Although this research project concerns differential geometry, a subject in pure mathematics, the methods and results significantly influence our understanding of the universe. In particular, this project investigates deep problems in the mathematical aspects of string theory, a topic of great current interest in theoretical physics. The investigator is involved in K-12 educational activities and also deeply involved in innovations in both undergraduate and graduate curricula.

The PI will work on several important problems in Kahler geometry and spectral theory. This project will continue a long-term investigation of the Weil-Peterson geometry on Calabi-Yau moduli, incorporating recent results in Kahler-Einstein geometry. The PI will study Agmon type estimates of the Bergman kernel and will continue to study the essential spectrum of differential forms on complete noncompact manifolds. The research will build on recent results of the PI and collaborators in complex geometry and spectral theory, including proof of the rationality of the Chern-Weil forms on moduli space of Kahler manifolds; construction of extremal metrics on certain ruled manifolds; study of the off-diagonal expansion of the Bergman kernels and the Poincare series of Bergman kernels on noncompact complete Kahler manifolds; proof of the Antunes-Freitas conjecture; and study of the relation between Dirichlet and Neumann eigenvalues. The long-term goal of this project is improved understanding of the geometry of moduli space; short term goals include study of the Bergman kernel expansion and the spectrum of differential forms on a complete non-compact manifold.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Principal investigator continues to work on some fundamental problems in differential geometry. During the review period, his main focus is on the fundamental operator on curved space: the Laplace operator, named after the French mathematician Pierre-Simon, marquis de Laplace (1749-1827). The methods and results influence to our understanding of the Universe. Thus they are related not only to pure mathematics but also to general relativity and quantum physics. 

During the review period, the principal investigator produced four papers. Among them, three are for peer reviewed journals or conference proceedings. One educational article, “Hearing the shape of a drum”, was written in Chinese and published in an educational magazine. Moreover, the article is also posted in two kinds of social media. As of today, the number of readings of the article is 2317. For a mathematics article, this draws a high rate of attention. 

The Principal investigator is also deeply involved in undergraduate and graduate education at the University of California, Irvine. He is serving the vice chair of undergraduate studies in the department. The jobs he is doing / has done include curriculum reform, using technology in education and outreach.

In summary, the principal investigator, during the last three years, have been working on both complex geometry and spectrum theory, and has essentially finished the projects described in his proposal. He paid a lot of attention to disseminate his results to general public. He also paid a lot of attention to diversity. His main collaborators are women mathematicians.
